claim: Breast cancer causes more deaths among women in the U.S. than lung cancer.

supporting.text: Breast cancer is the second leading cause of cancer-related deaths among women in the U.S., following lung cancer.

attacks.text: Breast cancer is the second leading cause of cancer-related deaths among women in the U.S., following lung cancer.
Recent studies show that in certain demographic groups, such as younger women, breast cancer mortality rates surpass those of lung cancer.
The overall mortality rate for lung cancer remains higher than breast cancer when considering all age groups and demographics.

supporting.text: Lung cancer has a higher mortality rate among women in the U.S. compared to breast cancer due to late-stage diagnosis and limited treatment options.

attacks.text: Lung cancer has a higher mortality rate among women in the U.S. compared to breast cancer due to late-stage diagnosis and limited treatment options.
Breast cancer is more prevalent than lung cancer among women in the U.S., leading to a higher absolute number of deaths despite a lower mortality rate.
Late-stage diagnosis of lung cancer is becoming less common due to improved screening methods like low-dose CT scans, reducing its mortality rate advantage.
Treatment options for lung cancer have expanded significantly in recent years with targeted therapies and immunotherapies, improving survival rates.

supporting.text: The American Cancer Society reports that lung cancer causes more deaths annually in U.S. women than breast cancer.

attacks.text: The American Cancer Society reports that lung cancer causes more deaths annually in U.S. women than breast cancer.
Breast cancer is more frequently diagnosed than lung cancer in women, which may lead to the perception that it causes more deaths.
Despite higher diagnosis rates, breast cancer has a higher survival rate compared to lung cancer, which is more lethal per case.
The American Cancer Society's data may not account for recent improvements in lung cancer treatments that could alter mortality rates.
Recent studies confirm that lung cancer remains the leading cause of cancer-related deaths in U.S. women, even with treatment advancements.

supporting.text: Advancements in early detection and treatment of breast cancer have reduced its mortality rate relative to lung cancer in women.

attacks.text: Advancements in early detection and treatment of breast cancer have reduced its mortality rate relative to lung cancer in women.
Lung cancer is often diagnosed at later stages, making it more lethal despite lower incidence rates compared to breast cancer.
Smoking rates among women have declined, reducing lung cancer incidence and mortality over time.
Breast cancer still has a higher incidence rate than lung cancer, which can lead to more total deaths even with lower mortality rates.
Improved screening programs for breast cancer have led to earlier detection, significantly improving survival rates.

supporting.text: Lung cancer's strong association with smoking contributes to its higher fatality rate among women compared to breast cancer.

attacks.text: Lung cancer's strong association with smoking contributes to its higher fatality rate among women compared to breast cancer.
Breast cancer has a higher incidence rate than lung cancer among women, leading to more total deaths despite lung cancer's higher fatality rate per case.
Advancements in breast cancer screening and treatment have significantly reduced its mortality rate, while lung cancer remains harder to detect early and treat effectively.
Smoking rates among women have declined in recent decades, which may reduce lung cancer deaths relative to breast cancer over time.
